By the age of twenty, he had memorized more than two million words of Mahayana and Hinayana sutras.
Dao'an's cousin was skilled in elephant taming. He rode and killed the king's white-eared elephant. The king was enraged and executed him, ordering:

No relatives dared to go.
Dao'an cried and buried him. The king was furious and wanted to execute Dao'an. Dao'an said:
The king killed him according to the law, and I buried him out of kinship. Neither violates the great principle. Why be angry?
The bystanders were chilled, but his expression remained as usual. The king admired his spirit and kept him for offerings.
Dao'an was well-versed in spells and all his practices were effective. He was called the Great Spell Master in the Western Regions.

Later, he followed the king into the mountains. The king was thirsty and needed water but could not find any. Shi Tanmo then secretly recited a spell, and water flowed from a rock. He then praised, saying:

The neighboring countries, hearing of this, all praised the king's virtue.
At that time, the rain and dew were very timely, and the people sang and danced. The king was delighted by his magical skills and treated him with deep favor.

Shi Tan warned Helian Bobo:

In the second year of Xuanhe of the Later Qin, Yao Xing crossed the Yellow River to attack the Later Yan at Baohan, with his crown prince Xing Guo leading the vanguard. They were defeated by the Later Yan army, and Xing Guo was captured.
Later, the Later Yan lost control, and Yao Xing and Xing Guo were both captured by Helian Ding. Ding was later defeated by the Tuyuhun, and Xing Guo was killed by a rebel soldier.
Yao Xing became furious, saying that Buddhism was ineffective, and he ordered the expulsion of monks under the age of fifty, all of whom were forced to return to lay life.

Previously, Yao Xing had a stone statue of the Buddha, sixteen feet tall, made for his mother. The statue then wept, with tears flowing down. Dao'an also spoke earnestly to admonish Yao Xing, who then changed his mind and repented.
